Comments_List: I learned basic skills regarding bacteria and fungi under specific concepts. For example, we learned how to spread a plate, use the dissecting microscope, and analyze different differential and selective media plates.

I learned how to perform environmental sampling to collect diverse microbes, study their biochemical properties, and identify them by 16S rRNA sequencing. In addition, I learned to use various techniques to study bacteria under a microscope, including simple stain, Gram stain, and live preps. I also gained insight into how to conjugate plasmids into bacteria in order to rescue motility and morphological defects in Caulobacter crescentus.

Learned valuable microbiology techniques and assays that both solidified understanding of experimental design and of theoretical concepts  from basics like streaking for singles, to trickier protocols like flagella staining. Good introduction to lab work, although those with lab experience may find it to be a bit slow.

I really came away from the course with a hands-on understanding of the kinds of microorganisms found in our surrounding environment, on our bodies, and in food products. We also learned how to isolate these microorganisms, how to count them, and how to identify them. Overall, I can say I now feel comfortable performing Gram staining, observing colony morphology using several different microscopes and imaging techniques, and interpreting the results of several biochemical tests.

The course is well-paced and not too stressful. However, the course can spend more time reviewing the concepts that we have learned. The textbook is nice, but there are also many extraneous details in the textbook. If professor can compose a lecture slide of pre-lab talk and post it on Canvas afterwards, it would be really helpful in understanding the concepts.

A strength of this course is its focus on teaching techniques used to identify bacteria in clinical settings. One weakness is that there is not a great deal of overlap with the microbio lecture. This course could be improved by incorporating more concepts from the lecture course.

Professor Dawson is a sweetheart, and the TA (Yashna) is amazing and very responsive. They love to walk around during experimentation time and answer questions or help  but by giving hints and facilitating understanding of the concept rather than just spoonfeeding instructions. Content criteria for the 4 lab report assignments were clearly outlined, although I wish there was a bit more guidance as to how things would be graded or what would be tested in the pop quizzes, since the level of difficulty seemed to vary by section.
I thought the labs were laid out well to take advantage of incubation times and make most classes fairly even in length. The lessons of each lab section were straightforward and easy to grasp.

Strengths 
- The lab exercises really do build on each other with each set of experiments, so there is a clear progression. 
- Professor Dawson gives great overviews of each lab at the beginning of the session
- The lab packets provide plenty of background
- The small class size really facilitates hands-on learning

Weaknesses 
- There are a couple of sessions when lab gets out an hour late and a few an hour early. This inconsistency is not ideal if you have a tight schedule. 
- Professor Dawson is usually fairly understanding but sometimes if you do something wrong, he can become visibly frustrated, which may make students more afraid to make mistakes.
I would recommend the course to another student, because the skills taught in this lab is very useful and fundamental.
Yes! Very helpful to augment lecture material. Fun atmosphere and learn a lot.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student, especially if they are interested in learning clinically relevant techniques to identify microorganisms.

Yes! Take it if youre looking for a solid lab credit to satisfy the MCDB research requirement, to build up a set of lab skills related to microbiology, or to learn science writing using data that actually feels experimental (and not just from a very controlled experiment).

This is definitely one of the most comfortably paced lab courses at Yale. The smaller size is conducive to learning, and it is super cool to take samples from our bodies and test for the presence of various bacteria!
